Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in the Boston Housing Court pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 and the court’s jurisdiction over landlord-tenant matters and housing code enforcement.

Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.raw_text: Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071, 1077–78 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord owes a tenant the right to quiet enjoyment of leased premises and has an implied obligation not to permit conditions that substantially interfere with the tenant’s beneficial use and enjoyment of the premises.

State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et.raw_text: State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq.
State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et.proposition: See, e.g., Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071, 1077–78 (D.C. Cir. 1970) (recognizing implied warranty of habitability and covenant of quiet enjoyment in residential leases); see also State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq. (Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation).

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111.proposition: The landlord’s obligations to keep premises fit for human habitation and to remedy housing code violations are embodied in Massachusetts statutory and regulatory law.

105 CMR 410.000.proposition: A landlord’s breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment occurs when the landlord's acts or omissions substantially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises — including the landlord’s failure to repair conditions that cause water infiltration, dampness, damage to possessions, or create an unsafe or uninhabitable environment.

105 CMR 410.200-410.350.proposition: - 105 CMR 410.200-410.350 (maintenance and required services; dampness, leaks, and structural defects);

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: A landlord’s breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment occurs when the landlord's acts or omissions substantially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises — including the landlord’s failure to repair conditions that cause water infiltration, dampness, damage to possessions, or create an unsafe or uninhabitable environment.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on recognizing and defining an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases, not on the covenant of quiet enjoyment or constructive eviction. While the facts include serious water leaks, sewage, unsafe conditions, and failure to repair, the court analyzes these as breaches of the implied warranty of habitability and explicitly states that, in light of its holding, the doctrine of constructive eviction is no longer viable. It does not frame the landlord’s omissions as a breach of quiet enjoyment or articulate the legal standard for that covenant, so it does not provide authority for the specific quiet-enjoyment proposition stated.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt: Therefore, we now hold expressly that in the rental of any residential dwelling unit an implied warranty exists in the lease, whether oral or written, that the landlord will deliver over and maintain, throughout the period of the tenancy, premises that are safe, clean and fit for human habitation. … Because of our holding in this case, the doctrine of constructive eviction, wherein the tenant must abandon in order to escape liability for rent, is no longer viable.

Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.raw_text: Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y.2d 316 (1979)
Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.proposition: - Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y.2d 316 (1979) (discussing landlord obligations);
Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.case_name: Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell
Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses and defines modern landlord obligations in residential leases under New York law, particularly through the implied warranty of habitability in Real Property Law § 235-b. It explains the landlord’s nondelegable duty to maintain premises in a habitable condition, the dependence of the tenant’s rent obligation on that duty, and the scope of conditions covered, thus directly “discussing landlord obligations.”
Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.relevant_excerpt: “Rather section 235-b of the Real Property Law was designed to give rise to an implied promise on the part of the landlord that both the demised premises and the areas within the landlord’s control are fit for human occupation at the inception of the tenancy and that they will remain so throughout the lease term.… Inasmuch as the landlord is vested with the ultimate control and responsibility for the building, it is he who has a corresponding nondelegable and nonwaivable duty to maintain it. The obligation of the tenant to pay rent is dependent upon the landlord’s satisfactory maintenance of the premises in habitable condition.”

Santiago v. Futterman, 390 Mass. 235 (19.proposition: - Santiago v. Futterman, 390 Mass. 235 (1983) (Massachusetts discussion of landlord-tenant obligations) [or other Massachusetts cases recognizing landlord duties to maintain premises];
Santiago v. Futterman, 390 Mass. 235 (19.case_name: Attorney General v. Department of Public Utilities
Santiago v. Futterman, 390 Mass. 235 (19.support_reasoning: This opinion is a public-utility ratemaking decision involving Boston Edison’s recovery of costs for an abandoned nuclear plant. It concerns administrative law, DPU authority, rate base, amortization, and related procedural issues, not landlord-tenant law. It does not discuss, recognize, or analyze any landlord obligations to maintain premises, so citing it for Massachusetts landlord-tenant duties is inaccurate.
Santiago v. Futterman, 390 Mass. 235 (19.relevant_excerpt: This court has not previously dealt with the question whether the department may lawfully permit a utility to recover prudently incurred costs of a construction project reasonably abandoned prior to its completion. The appellants point out that Pilgrim II never generated any electricity and argue that, until such an asset has “come on line,” its costs may not be reflected in rates. They point to no statutory basis for this argument. We have considered the right of a utility to reflect in its rates the prudently incurred cost of plant reasonably abandoned before it was fully depreciated.
